item.title: [SPR-163] Create a notion of "Warnings"
item.description:
There is a notion of Errors <<interface>>, so during validation there might be some property values rejected. We treat Errors as critical e.g. in Controllers after validation we check Errors collection and if not empty we DO NOT proceed (invoke the middle tier). There are some use cases however that state - some validations should be treated as WARNINGS e.g. if the rule is not satisfied, just display a warning message to the user, but still proceed with the workflow.

I'm not sure if that's been solved already, but in any case, would be nice to create a Warnings <<interface>> to distinguish between those to concepts (Errors -> do not proceed, Warnings -> still proceed)

  • Dmitriy.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
I also need this improvement, in addition after the user performs a task there are usually three possible outcomes, an error occurs, success with warning, total success.

It would be better if we could add Success messages as well. As it stands at the moment I have both my success,error and warning messages all in the same file but I only use SpringBind to display my error messages.

It would be nice to provide this feature. Actually, it is like the logging level. Error, warning, info (success message), or even debug (more details from inside the process).

Moreover, all those messages could be created in any layer: business or integration (persistence), and it could be across different components, not only in the UI validation. That means a ThreadLocal may be used to store the accumulated messages.

+1

SPR-1044 is somewhat connected to this issue, so a good solution here would probably render SPR-1044 obsolete.

we have this in a non-spring app today,and we actually had 2 kinds of 'warnings'

1. informational warning - whatever was validated worked, but display a message the user should be aware of<br>

2. override/confirm required warning - whatever was validated is ok, but you need to confirm that you really want to do this thing - a good example is a duplicate warning - we see you havea transaction like what you are about to submit, which is ok, but just in case this is an accidental duplicate you need to submit again to override/confirm this is really what you meant to do.

Not sure this difference is universal enough to introduce into the framework, but I suspect is might beatleastworth considering, while you are in there tweaking the Errors validation idea.

I would also like this functionality. It would be helpful if it was easy to redirect the user to the form that raised 'warning' validations with the data that they entered there... if the user makes changes and submits the form run the validations again, otherwise if they just submit the form then continue with the action. Although perhaps this is better handled by Spring Webflow?

I would be also interrested with this evolution for a secondary purpose:
I want to display warning messages on validation:

In fact, I want to warn (or inform) users about some validation problems (that are not critical, not errors in facts). if the user submit the form again with no changes, I want to perform the submit.

Usually in our web application we have three type of errors:
1) Error messages (the user cannot continue, he has to correct something on the web page).
2) Warning messages (the user must select a check-box to confirm that he has read the message and he want to continue anyway).
3) Info messages (the user can continue)

Actually we have to manage "warning" and "info" messages inside the controller, but it would be nice if we could handle them directly inside the validator.

Davide.

Closed duplicate SPR-1423. I think the Spring framework knowing about warnings, info, errors, and possibly other types of messages is good, but as a workaround we now define an session scoped aop "messages" proxy which business objects, incl. validators can add messages to. It works pretty well, but probably not as good as built in Spring support would.

Forgive my ignorance of the development process - I see there are several log entries of people making changes to version 3.x. Is there an update on what the status is of this request?

I have a similar need for validation to sometimes generate warnings that do not affect process flow, but can be displayed. I was able to work-around this for use case scenarios where the process flows forward to a result page, but so far have not figured out how to do it when other aspects of validation flow the process back to the form page.

Thanks,

Rebeccah
